title: Queen Maxima oozes elegance in a royal blue gown as she visits a textile factory in India
text:
Queen Maxima of the Netherlands was positively glowing today as she visited a small textile factory helping people out of poverty in India on her third official day of her five-day state visit to the country.

The radiant royal, 48, appeared in her element as she met with women working at the operation run by the Dutch organisation Tiny Miracles in Gol Maidan, Mumbai.

Maxima, who was accompanied by her husband King Willem-Alexander, 52, displayed her ethereal beauty in a flowing blue dress featuring ruffled detailing on the hem as she made her way through the inner-city streets.

The monarch teamed her garment, which featured a cut-out below the neckline, with a stylish blue headpiece that was decorated with delicate feathers.

Queen Maxima of the Netherlands (left), 48, looked elegant as she joined her husband King Willem-Alexander (right), 52, on a visit to a textile factory in Gol Maidan, Mumbai, on Wednesday

The radiant royal sported a flowing blue dress that featured ruffled detailing on the hem as she met with staff working for the Dutch-run project Tiny Miracles

During the day, the queen sat down to speak with workers who had received employment through the organisation's work

Maxima accessorised her look with an eye-catching pair of blue tassel drop dangle earrings and a gold and silver bracelet on either side of her wrists.

Letting her blonde locks cascade down her shoulders in loose waves, the queen added further glamour to her look with a statement silver watch.

The mother-of-three daughters - Catharina-Amalia, 14, Alexia, 12, and Ariane, 10 - completed her look with a snakeskin clutch bag and a pair of matching heels as she greeted workers with her husband.

Maxima appeared in high spirits as she made her way through the narrow streets and spoke with those being helped by the Dutch-run project Tiny Miracles.

Maxima appeared in high spirits as she walked through the inner-city streets spoke with those working for Tiny Miracles

While inside the textile factory, Maxima sat down to speak with workers who had been lifted out of poverty

The queen, who teamed her garment with a stylish blue headpiece that was decorated with delicate feathers, later posed for a photo with staff at the factory and her husband

Meanwhile Willem-Alexander looked dapper in a striped blue suit which he teamed with a white shirt and patterned red tie.

During the day, the royal couple were seen listening to women who had found employment through the charity and also spoke to those who helped run the project in the poverty-stricken area.

They later visited a school to meet with the children of the employees who are now receiving an education through the project's work.

The project, which was created by Dutch founder Laurien Meuter, has helped many people out of poverty in India by providing them with work in sewing machine factories.

Following their visit, the official Twitter account of the Embassy of India in The Hague, the Netherlands, wrote: 'HM King Willem-Alexander & HM Queen Maxima visited Tiny Miracles in Mumbai, which aims to help communities in poor neighbourhoods get out of poverty and become self-sufficient by creating employment and offering employees social services such as education and healthcare.'

The royal couple later visited a school that saw the children of employees working at the factory receive an education

Maxima was all smiles as she interacted with the excited children who are now being offered a chance out of poverty through the organisation's work

The monarch let her blonde locks cascade down her shoulders in loose waves as she waved to the crowds

Following their visit, the Embassy of India in The Hague, the Netherlands, shared their support of the visit

The royal couple's visit to Mumbai comes a day after they attended the India-Netherlands Technology Summit at the JW Marriott Hotel in New Delhi for the 25th edition of the high-profile event.

Following their attendance at the business event, the couple also visited the sandstone and marble mausoleum of Safjar Jang who was the ruler of the Indian state of Oudh.

On their first official day in India, the queen and her husband, who landed in India on Sunday evening, joined prime minister Narendra Modi to visit the open-air memorial of the Indian civil rights leader Mahatma Gandhi in Raj Ghat.

On the same day the royal couple were treated to a lavish state banquet at the Rashtrapati Bhavan Palace in the Indian capital.

The royal visit, which marks King Willem-Alexander's first Indian state visit since his ascension to the throne in 2013, will also see the couple visit the 'Indo-Dutch interactions in the time of Rembrandt' exhibition at the Chhatrapati Shivaji Museum in Mumbai.

Yesterday the royal couple (centre) attended the India-Netherlands Technology Summit at the JW Marriott Hotel in New Delhi

Following the summit they visited the beautiful sandstone and marble mausoleum of Safjar Jang who was the ruler of the Indian state of Oudh
description: Queen Maxima of the Netherlands, 48, looked elegant in a flowing blue dress that featured ruffled detailing as she visited a small textile factory in Gol Maidan, Mumbai, on Wednesday.
